channel.title: Comments for Sorry for the Spam

item.title: Comment on A Tor of the Dark Web by Counter Globalist
item.dc:creator: Counter Globalist
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2012/08/a-tor-of-the-dark-web/#comment-227">whatever</a>.
Censorship is imposed on another person via force. Your argument is self defeating. Using force against other humans is wrong.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to whatever.

Censorship is imposed on another person via force.
Your argument is self defeating.
Using force against other humans is wrong.

item.description:
Any tech article that makes me laugh gets extra credit.
"Remember that time you were watching Netflix and you blacked out because your cat sucker-punched you?"
item.content:encoded:
Any tech article that makes me laugh gets extra credit.

“Remember that time you were watching Netflix and you blacked out because your cat sucker-punched you?”

item.title: Comment on A Puntitled Framework for Evaluating the Quality of Puns by rfong'12
item.dc:creator: rfong'12
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Daniel Schultz.

Slant references seem difficult because they’re simultaneously underconstrained and have high semantic dimensionality.

Mapping “hate accessories” to “kill the messenger” has some pretty expensive steps, which might be reduced by storing word-sense-similarity lookups much looser than synonymity
– very loose semantic association between “hate” and “kill”
– one word sense of “accessories” is a hypernym of a phrase containing “messenger”

item.title: Comment on A Puntitled Framework for Evaluating the Quality of Puns by elplatt
item.dc:creator: elplatt
item.description: Proposal 1: modifier for the number of interpretations that are mutually, semantically consistent.
item.content:encoded: Proposal 1: modifier for the number of interpretations that are mutually, semantically consistent.

item.title: Comment on A Puntitled Framework for Evaluating the Quality of Puns by Daniel Schultz
item.dc:creator: Daniel Schultz
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2016/03/a-puntitled-framework-for-evaluating-the-quality-of-puns/#comment-277">rfong'12</a>.
This is all awesome -- also, FWIW you might be able to generate slant references by analyzing a corpus for commonly repeated phrases.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to rfong’12.

This is all awesome — also, FWIW you might be able to generate slant references by analyzing a corpus for commonly repeated phrases.

item.title: Comment on A Puntitled Framework for Evaluating the Quality of Puns by rfong'12
item.dc:creator: rfong'12
item.description:
Ugh I thought my friend invented the n-dimensional pun terminology. Thanks for collating these into one place! I think it'd be funnier (and more NLP-relevant) to refer to "dual definitions" as "word-sense re-ambiguation". Slant references sound difficult to achieve programmatically.
I've been doing a lot of what I call "shittyNLP" recently, which is just simple deterministic messing around with text for amusement purposes.
You might enjoy my Pun Assistinator (phonetic superstring lookup) - http://rfong.github.io/pun/ and this portmanteau generator (or couple name generator for your friends) - https://gist.github.com/rfong/1188f5128d6e443ede98
item.content:encoded:
Ugh I thought my friend invented the n-dimensional pun terminology. Thanks for collating these into one place! I think it’d be funnier (and more NLP-relevant) to refer to “dual definitions” as “word-sense re-ambiguation”. Slant references sound difficult to achieve programmatically.

I’ve been doing a lot of what I call “shittyNLP” recently, which is just simple deterministic messing around with text for amusement purposes.

You might enjoy my Pun Assistinator (phonetic superstring lookup) – http://rfong.github.io/pun/
and this portmanteau generator (or couple name generator for your friends) – https://gist.github.com/rfong/1188f5128d6e443ede98

item.title: Comment on Introducing Opened Captions by Daniel Schultz
item.dc:creator: Daniel Schultz
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2012/10/introducing-opened-captions/#comment-256">Nick Poulos</a>.
It's up now! Sorry for not mentioning sooner -- and the uptime is now better... should last for a while now
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Nick Poulos.

It’s up now! Sorry for not mentioning sooner — and the uptime is now better… should last for a while now
